candidates.title: Did a Bear Chase a Skier Down a Mountain?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a bear chasing a skier down a mountain in Romania in January 2021.
Rating:
True
About this rating
In 2016, a video went viral that supposedly showed a bear chasing a snowboarder down a mountain. Since that video was fake  it featured computer generated imagery  we were skeptical when we came across a similar video in January 2021 supposedly showing a bear chasing a skier down a mountain.
This is a real video.
The Romanian news outlet Digi 24 reported that this video was filmed on a ski slope in Predeal, Romania. The incident was filmed by multiple people on the chairlift who watched the scene unfold below. Digi 24 reports that the people on the chairlift yelled (translated via Google):
"Give it faster, give it faster! Come on, the bear is chasing you ! Give it faster! God forbid, don't look back!"
Here's another video of the incident:
The man in the video escaped unharmed.
Ion Zaharia, the county gendarmerie inspectorate, said that when the person realized what was happening, the skier threw a backpack on the ground. This distracted the bear and allowed the person to ski to safety.
A video report from Obiectiv 3 shows the bear ending the pursuit after finding the bag.
Officials on the mountain said that they may  as they have done when similar situations arose in years past  attempt to relocate the bear away from the ski slopes.
This incident may seem unusual to some viewers as they have been told (incorrectly) that one way to evade a bear is to run (or ski) downhill. Bears, however, can run downhills at surprising speeds. According to the National Wildlife Federation, bears are nearly as fast as horses, and can reach speeds of 35 mph:
Myth: Bears cant run downhill.
If youre being chased by a bear, dont run downhill! Bears can run as fast as a horse (35 mph), and they can do it uphill, downhill, and everything in between. A bear can outrun you no matter what, so if you see one in the wild do not try to run away from it. Instead, you should stand tall, wave your arms, and talk loudly but calmly. Back away slowly, but stop moving if the bear follows you.
candidates.description: We were skeptical when this video came our way, but let's just say it put to rest the myth that bears can't run downhill.

candidates.title: Does This Photograph Capture a Bear Chasing a Cyclist?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows a bear chasing a cyclist down a mountain road.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A photograph supposedly showing a bear chasing a bicyclist down a mountain road has long circulated online, with various humorous captions attached to it over the years. In February 2019, for example, the Facebook page "Inspire Uplift" shared the image along with the caption "Meals on Wheels in Canada":
The original photograph (which featured a bear but no biker) can be traced to a September 2014 post on photographer Adonis Arias' Tumblr page. That posting didn't provide much information about the picture other than it was taken in Yellowstone National Park. (We reached out to Arias for more information but did not hear back prior to publication of this story.)
Here's a look at the original image (right) and the doctored version (left):
candidates.description: One version of this was captioned: "Some days it's hard to find motivation. Some days motivation finds you."

result.explanation: Source 1 describes a verified incident of a bear chasing a skier down a mountain.  Source 2 debunks a manipulated image of a bear chasing a cyclist. The news caption, "A bear chasing a bicyclist down a mountain road", is inconsistent with the verified evidence. While Source 1 supports the occurrence of a bear chasing someone downhill, it involves a skier, not a bicyclist.  The caption is therefore inaccurate in its description of the event, and the imagery in Source 2 provides further reason to doubt the accuracy of the claim.  The caption uses elements of a real event (Source 1) to imply a similar, but unverified event (bicyclist).

final_result.explanation: The image shows a bear and a cyclist on a mountain road, seemingly in pursuit.  However, external evidence reveals the image is manipulated; the original image did not include the cyclist.  While source 1 verifies a similar event (bear chasing a skier), the news caption's claim about a bicyclist is inaccurate and unsupported by reliable evidence. The internal check had low confidence due to a lack of entities to compare against the caption. The external check, with strong evidence from reliable sources, demonstrates the caption's inaccuracy. Combining both results indicates the caption is out of context.
